newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: RUGBY UNION-ACT BOOK HOME SEMI AFTER BEATING HURRICANES.
newsitem.headline: RUGBY UNION-ACT BOOK HOME SEMI AFTER BEATING HURRICANES.

text.p: The ACT Brumbies blew the Wellington Hurricanes off Athletic Park on Sunday and booked themselves a Super 12 home semi-final in Canberra.
Outplaying the home side in both the backs and forwards in front of a capacity 40,000 crowd, ACT won a brilliant game of rugby by 38-29.
ACT finished the competition in second position behind Auckland and the Hurricanes in the third and the teams will have a rematch next weekend but with ACT having home advantage.
In a whirlwind start, ACT, playing with a strong breeze stunned the Hurricanes with two tries in the first quarter of an hour.
George Gregan, the most effective player on the day, started the five-try spree after just five minutes, darting through a gap to complete a series of attacks.
Minutes later winger Joe Roff came into the backline from the wrong side to put fellow winger Mitch Hardy in.
A David Knox penalty put the Brumbies 15-0 up after as many minutes.
Two penalties from Jon Preston narrowed the gap but a try by flanker Owen Finegan from a brilliant backhand flip from Gregan put the Brumbies up 22-6 at halftime.
A try to Filo Tiatia in the first minute after the break set the Hurricanes on course to overhaull ACT and that was soon followed by a Preston penalty.
But then Roff then scored again and Preston replied with a penalty from half way.
Hardy's second try midway through the half was the best of the day as the Brumbries forwards drove up the centre and a quick hands transfer to the winger set up the try.
However, Wellington were not done. Christian Cullen, who had been well contained, scored a brilliant individual try beating opponents for pace.
And then with minutes to go Cullen scored a second try chasing a kick through to give Wellington a chance to snatch a last-minute victory.
